abstract: The Deal Professor looks at how Bank of America’s chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, used the material adverse condition clause in the Merrill Lynch deal as a keystone in a masterful game of spin.
snippet: The Deal Professor looks at how Bank of America’s chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, used the material adverse condition clause in the Merrill Lynch deal as a keystone in a masterful game of spin.
lead_paragraph: As someone who writes about deals, I find it oddly satisfying to see members of Congress asking questions about material adverse change clauses. Perhaps these members even understand the questions they are asking about them. But I have no doubt that the person they questioned Thursday about these MAC clauses — Bank of America‘s chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis — is quite conversant in their nuances. For he is using the MAC clause as a keystone in a masterful game of spin.
